learning_outcomes.description: make use of improved critical reading skills required for undergraduate study
make use of improved academic writing skills and the clear presentation of your ideas
better employ key concepts and imaginative aspects of thinking necessary to good problem solving.

assessments.due_date:
9/03/2026 - 23/03/2026

The online quiz will be available for students via Blackboard Assessment from 12:01 AM Monday 9th of March to 11:59 PM Monday 9th of March and from 12:01 AM Monday 23rd of March to 11:59 PM Monday 23rd of March. From the beginning of the test, 1 hour is allocated for its completion.
assessments.task_description:
A short quiz on concepts covered so far. 

NOTE: This assessment task evaluates student’s abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
You are asked to select and perform an analysis of argument in a media article and to provide an additional written commentary of 800 words that analyses and evaluates the article as an argument, including suggestions on how the argument could be improved and what key questions you would ask the author. These could be questions of clarity or to get more information. If more information is requested, it is important that you explain why you are seeking it.

This important and useful exercise, building on work covered in the first half of the course, aims to develop critical writing skills essential for undergraduate study, including the study of philosophy. The topic will be discussed, the assignment described in detail, and handouts made available during lectures (and on the Course Blackboard).

A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the Assessment folder in Blackboard for this course.


Students are responsible for familiarizing themselves with School policy regarding academic advice, assessment, plagiarism, etc. as stated on the School’s web-page http://www.uq.edu.au/hprc/index.html?page=49903&pid=21371   PLAGIARISM is an academic offence and will be penalized. Useful information may also be found on the UQ Cybrary web-page under “Advice & Training – UseIts”.

NOTE: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit an electronic copy (for plagiarism checking and to facilitate marking) through Turnitin under 'Assessment' on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: The participation marks for this subject include completion of a series of tasks on the Kialo platform and in-tutorial participation. Details will be provided in class. Kialo submission are required at the end of weeks 2, 4, 6, 8 and 12.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: The end of semester exam will be a combination of short and extended response items. The exam will be completed using the Inspera platform and students will bring their own devises to the exam.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1

We don't think like we think we think. An overview of how we think, challenging common ideas of what goes on when we are thinking.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1 We don't think like we think we think. An overview of how we think, challenging common ideas of what goes on when we are thinking.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2

What can go wrong? Cognitive biases and other blocks to effective thinking are explored and discussed.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
